slides.title: Introduction to Indian Polity
slides.content:
Indian Polity covers the political system, constitution, governance, and administrative structure of India. This is an important topic for CISF Constable Fire exam.

**What is Polity?**
Polity refers to the system of government and political organization of a country.

**Topics Covered:**
1. Indian Constitution
2. Fundamental Rights and Duties
3. Union Government (President, PM, Parliament)
4. State Government (Governor, CM, Legislature)
5. Judiciary
6. Important Constitutional Bodies

**Indian Constitution:**
- **Adopted:** 26 November 1949
- **Came into force:** 26 January 1950 (Republic Day)
- **Longest written constitution** in the world
- **Father of Constitution:** Dr. B.R. Ambedkar
- **Drafted by:** Constituent Assembly
- **Chairman:** Dr. Rajendra Prasad
- **Preamble:** Begins with "We, the people of India"

**Preamble Keywords:**
- **SOVEREIGN:** Independent authority
- **SOCIALIST:** Social and economic equality
- **SECULAR:** All religions equal
- **DEMOCRATIC:** Power to people
- **REPUBLIC:** Elected head of state

**Why Important?**
- 5-7 questions from polity
- Tests constitutional knowledge
- Important for government jobs
- Covers current political structure

Understanding polity helps you know how India is governed and your rights as a citizen.

slides.title: Fundamental Rights and Duties
slides.content:
**Fundamental Rights (Part III):**

Originally 7, now **6 Fundamental Rights** (Right to Property removed in 1978)

**1. Right to Equality (Articles 14-18)**
- Equality before law
- No discrimination on religion, race, caste, sex
- Equal opportunity in employment
- Abolition of untouchability
- Abolition of titles (except military and academic)

**2. Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22)**
- Freedom of speech and expression
- Freedom to assemble peacefully
- Freedom to form associations
- Freedom of movement
- Freedom of residence
- Freedom of profession
- Protection of life and liberty

**3. Right against Exploitation (Articles 23-24)**
- Prohibition of human trafficking
- Prohibition of child labor (below 14 years)

**4. Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28)**
- Freedom of conscience and religion
- Manage religious institutions
- Freedom from religious instruction in state schools

**5. Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30)**
- Protection of interests of minorities
- Right to establish educational institutions

**6. Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32)**
- Right to approach Supreme Court
- Dr. Ambedkar called it "Heart and Soul" of Constitution

**Fundamental Duties (Part IV-A):**

**11 Fundamental Duties** (Added in 1976 by 42nd Amendment)

- Respect Constitution, National Flag, Anthem
- Follow ideals of freedom struggle
- Protect sovereignty and integrity
- Defend country
- Promote harmony
- Preserve composite culture
- Protect environment, forests, wildlife
- Develop scientific temper
- Safeguard public property
- Strive for excellence
- Provide opportunities for education (6-14 years) - 11th duty added in 2002

slides.title: Union Government - President and Vice President
slides.content:
**President of India:**

**Position:**
- Head of State (not head of government)
- First citizen of India
- Supreme Commander of Armed Forces
- Part of Parliament (President + Lok Sabha + Rajya Sabha)

**Qualifications:**
- Citizen of India
- Minimum age: 35 years
- Qualified for Lok Sabha membership
- Should not hold office of profit

**Term:**
- 5 years
- Can be re-elected
- Resignation: To Vice President
- Impeachment: By Parliament

**Election:**
- Elected by Electoral College
- Elected members of Parliament + State Legislatures
- Indirect election

**Powers:**
- **Executive:** Appoints PM, Governors, Judges
- **Legislative:** Summons Parliament, gives assent to bills
- **Judicial:** Grants pardons, reprieves
- **Emergency:** Can declare three types of emergencies
- **Diplomatic:** Represents India internationally

**Current (as general knowledge):**
- **First President:** Dr. Rajendra Prasad
- **First Woman President:** Pratibha Patil
- **Youngest President:** Neelam Sanjiva Reddy

**Vice President:**

**Position:**
- Second highest constitutional post
- Ex-officio Chairman of Rajya Sabha
- Acts as President when President is absent

**Qualifications:**
- Citizen of India
- Minimum age: 35 years
- Qualified for Rajya Sabha membership

**Term:**
- 5 years
- Can be re-elected

**Election:**
- Elected by Electoral College
- Members of both Houses of Parliament

**Note:** President and Vice President cannot be members of Parliament or State Legislature.

slides.title: Parliament and Prime Minister
slides.content:
**Parliament of India:**

**Structure:** Bicameral (Two Houses)
1. **Lok Sabha** (House of People) - Lower House
2. **Rajya Sabha** (Council of States) - Upper House

**Lok Sabha:**
- **Maximum Strength:** 552 members
  - 530 from States
  - 20 from Union Territories
  - 2 nominated (Anglo-Indians) - now abolished
- **Current Strength:** 543
- **Term:** 5 years
- **Presiding Officer:** Speaker
- **Qualifications:** Min age 25 years, voter of any constituency
- **Majority mark:** 272 (for forming government)

**Rajya Sabha:**
- **Maximum Strength:** 250 members
  - 238 from States and UTs
  - 12 nominated by President (experts in art, science, literature, social service)
- **Current Strength:** 245
- **Term:** 6 years (1/3rd retire every 2 years)
- **Presiding Officer:** Vice President of India
- **Qualifications:** Min age 30 years
- **Not subject to dissolution**

**Prime Minister:**

**Position:**
- Head of Government
- Real executive authority
- Leader of majority party in Lok Sabha
- Chairman of Cabinet

**Powers:**
- Leads the government
- Recommends President to appoint ministers
- Allocates portfolios
- Chairs Cabinet meetings
- Chief spokesperson of government
- Link between President and Cabinet

**Cabinet:**
- Council of Ministers headed by PM
- Collective responsibility to Lok Sabha
- Can be removed by vote of no confidence

**Important:**
- **First PM:** Jawaharlal Nehru
- **First Woman PM:** Indira Gandhi
- **Longest serving PM:** Jawaharlal Nehru (16+ years)

question.questionText: How many Fundamental Rights are there in the Indian Constitution?
question.explanation: There are 6 Fundamental Rights in the Indian Constitution. Originally there were 7, but the Right to Property was removed from Fundamental Rights in 1978 by the 44th Amendment.

slides.title: State Government and Judiciary
slides.content:
**State Government:**

**Governor:**
- Constitutional head of state
- Appointed by President
- Term: 5 years
- Minimum age: 35 years
- Can be governor of more than one state
- Functions similar to President at state level

**Chief Minister:**
- Head of state government
- Real executive authority in state
- Leader of majority party in State Assembly
- Appointed by Governor

**State Legislature:**

**Unicameral (One House) - Vidhan Sabha only:**
- Most states have only Vidhan Sabha

**Bicameral (Two Houses):**
- Vidhan Sabha (Lower House)
- Vidhan Parishad (Upper House)
- States with Vidhan Parishad: UP, Bihar, Maharashtra, Karnataka, Telangana, AP (6 states)

**Vidhan Sabha:**
- Maximum: 500 members, Minimum: 60 members
- Term: 5 years
- Min age: 25 years

**Vidhan Parishad:**
- 1/3rd of Vidhan Sabha strength
- Term: 6 years (1/3rd retire every 2 years)
- Min age: 30 years

**Judiciary:**

**Three-tier System:**

**1. Supreme Court (Apex Court)**
- Located: New Delhi
- Judges: Chief Justice + 33 other judges (34 total)
- Retirement age: 65 years
- Appointed by: President
- Original, Appellate, Advisory jurisdiction
- Guardian of Constitution

**2. High Courts (State Level)**
- Each state has High Court (some share)
- Retirement age: 62 years
- Chief Justice + other judges

**3. District and Lower Courts**
- Subordinate courts
- District Judge, Magistrate courts

slides.title: Important Constitutional Bodies
slides.content:
**Election Commission of India:**
- Conducts elections (Parliament, State Legislatures, President, VP)
- **Chief Election Commissioner** + 2 Election Commissioners
- Independent constitutional body
- Established: 25 January 1950
- HQ: New Delhi

**Union Public Service Commission (UPSC):**
- Conducts civil services examinations
- Advises government on recruitment
- Chairman + members
- HQ: New Delhi

**Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG):**
- Audits government accounts
- Independent authority
- Reports to Parliament
- Appointed by President
- Term: 6 years or 65 years age

**Finance Commission:**
- Recommends distribution of taxes between Centre and States
- Constituted every 5 years
- Chairman + 4 members

**National Commission for Scheduled Castes (NCSC):**
- Protects rights of SCs
- Inquires into complaints

**National Commission for Scheduled Tribes (NCST):**
- Protects rights of STs
- Similar functions as NCSC

**Attorney General:**
- Chief legal advisor to government
- Highest law officer
- Appointed by President

**State Public Service Commission (SPSC):**
- State level recruitment
- Functions like UPSC at state level

**National Human Rights Commission (NHRC):**
- Protects human rights
- Established: 1993
- HQ: New Delhi

**Central Information Commission (CIC):**
- Implements Right to Information Act
- Chief Information Commissioner + Commissioners

**Central Vigilance Commission (CVC):**
- Anti-corruption body
- Established: 1964

slides.title: Important Constitutional Amendments
slides.content:
**Key Constitutional Amendments:**

**1st Amendment (1951):**
- Restrictions on freedom of speech
- Added 9th Schedule

**7th Amendment (1956):**
- Reorganization of states on linguistic basis

**24th Amendment (1971):**
- Parliament can amend Fundamental Rights

**42nd Amendment (1976) - Mini Constitution:**
- Added SOCIALIST, SECULAR, INTEGRITY to Preamble
- Added Fundamental Duties
- Changed supremacy from judiciary to parliament

**44th Amendment (1978):**
- Right to Property removed from Fundamental Rights
- Made it legal right (Article 300A)

**61st Amendment (1989):**
- Reduced voting age from 21 to 18 years

**73rd Amendment (1992):**
- Panchayati Raj institutions
- Rural local self-government

**74th Amendment (1992):**
- Municipalities
- Urban local self-government

**86th Amendment (2002):**
- Free and compulsory education for children 6-14 years
- Made it Fundamental Right (Article 21A)
- Added 11th Fundamental Duty

**91st Amendment (2003):**
- Anti-defection law strengthened
- Limited Council of Ministers size

**101st Amendment (2016):**
- Goods and Services Tax (GST)

**103rd Amendment (2019):**
- 10% reservation for economically weaker sections (EWS)

**Important Points:**
- Total 100+ amendments till date
- Parliament can amend Constitution
- Basic structure cannot be amended (Kesavananda Bharati case)

**Remember:** Focus on major amendments and their key features.
